title: Goldman Sachs' David Solomon warns of ‘wage inflation everywhere' as expenses jump
text:
The chief executive of Goldman Sachs has warned of “wage inflation everywhere” after a big jump in expenses hit fourth-quarter profits at the Wall Street bank.

In an interview with the Financial Times, David Solomon said that Goldman like other large companies was contending with higher wage demands from its employees. “There's no question that inflationary pressures around compensation had an impact,” he added.

Solomon was speaking after Goldman on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $3.8bn, or $10.81 per share, compared with $4.36bn, or $12.08 per share, in the same period last year.

That was a bigger drop than analysts had predicted, with the consensus forecast for net income at about $4.1bn, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

Goldman shares closed down 7 per cent at $354.40.

Headcount at Goldman grew 8 per cent in 2021 to 43,900 while pay also jumped as the bank paid bumper bonuses to reward staff — particularly investment bankers — for record annual profits last year.

Pay including bonuses was up 31 per cent year on year in the fourth quarter at $3.2bn, more than the $2.9bn analysts had forecast. Annual salary expenses were up 33 per cent at $17.7bn in 2021, mirroring the bank's net revenue growth for the year.

Bank stocks were already under pressure after JPMorgan Chase warned on Friday that it would miss profitability targets this year in part owing to higher expenses. Goldman exacerbated those worries by reporting operating expenses of $7.3bn for the fourth quarter, up 23 per cent from a year earlier and more than the $6.4bn analysts had expected.

The results “are a stark reminder that wage inflation is hitting the banking sector hard”, said Octavio Marenzi, chief executive of Opimas, a capital markets management consultancy.

Despite earnings missing estimates in the fourth quarter, full-year net profit for 2021 came in at $21.2bn, more than double the level in 2020 and easily the largest in the bank's history.

Revenue earned in investment banking from advising on mergers and acquisitions, initial public offerings and debt deals was up 45 per cent to $3.8bn in the fourth quarter due to a surge in dealmaking activity. JPMorgan last week reported investment banking revenue rose 28 per cent year on year to $3.2bn. 

It was the eighth consecutive quarter of year-on-year revenue growth for Goldman's investment bank, although analysts expected the streak to end in early 2022 following the high bar set last year.

However, the dealmaking boom failed to make up for a weaker performance in the bank's trading division. Revenue at the unit, which had a bumper year in 2020 because of heavy trading volume during the pandemic, was down 7 per cent at $3.98bn year on year, missing analysts' forecasts of $4.3bn.

Solomon said: “There's nothing to change our view of the [trading] business.”

Asked about the decline in Goldman's stock price on Tuesday, Solomon said: “I like it better on days when the stock goes up . . . We're focused on executing our plan, not on short-term gyrations of the stock price.”

The investment banking and trading divisions accounted for more than 60 per cent of Goldman's revenues. The units are still by far its biggest profit engines two years after Solomon outlined plans to focus on newer businesses such as consumer and transaction banking.

Solomon said he would give investors a “refresh” on the bank's targets next month.
